title: MQ-25 Stingray Has Begun Taxi Tests (Updated)
summary: The U.S. Navy's MQ-25 Stingray aerial refueling drone has commenced its first low-speed taxi tests, marking a significant step from development to physical hardware. This milestone brings the unmanned aircraft closer to its anticipated first flight and eventual deployment aboard American aircraft carriers.

title: MQ-25 Stingray Has Begun Taxi Tests (Updated)
summary: The initial production-representative MQ-25 Stingray tanker drone for the U.S. Navy has completed its first low-speed taxi test at Boeing's facility. The Navy is now targeting an early 2026 first flight for the uncrewed aircraft, following delays, and Lockheed Martin is under contract to develop an underlying common control architecture for similar unmanned systems.

title: Boeing's MQ-25 First Flight Delayed to 2026
summary: The inaugural flight of the U.S. Navy's Boeing MQ-25 Stingray has been postponed to early 2026, as the aircraft undergoes extensive ground tests and systems certification. Despite this delay, the program remains crucial for integrating unmanned aircraft into carrier operations, with the Navy also collaborating with Lockheed Martin on the Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control System (UMCS).

title: U.S. Navy MQ-25A Stingray tanker drone anchors future carrier operations in FY2026 plan
summary: The U.S. Navy's Acquisition Program 2026 report confirms the MQ-25A Stingray and its Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control System are progressing towards early operational capability, indicating a shift towards sustained operational use. The report, released in July 2025, also notes that Lockheed Martin's MD-5E ground control station has been hosted on a carrier, becoming central to the Navy's emerging Unmanned Air Warfare Center.

title: Navy's drone refueler delayed again
summary: The initial operational capability for the MQ-25 Stingray has been pushed back once more, now anticipated for the third quarter of fiscal 2027, revised from earlier targets of 2024 and 2026. This delay is revealed in new budget documents, despite ongoing ground testing and the expectation for the drone's first flight in 2025.

title: US Navy to fly MQ-25 autonomous refueller from aircraft carrier in 2026
summary: The first Boeing MQ-25 autonomous refueling aircraft is slated for integration with a US Navy aircraft carrier in 2026, following its expected initial flight in late 2025. The test version, T1, has already successfully demonstrated fuel transfer to various USN aircraft, including the Lockheed Martin F-35C.

title: MQ-25 Program Update with Boeing at Sea Air Space 2024
summary: Troy Rutherford, VP and Program Manager for Boeing, provided updates on the MQ-25 program at Sea Air Space 2024, highlighting a contract award for two test aircraft in March 2024. The MQ-25 Stingray is set to become the world's first operational, carrier-based unmanned aircraft, offering crucial aerial refueling and intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities.

title: MQ-25 Stingray Carrier Based Unmanned Aerial System (CBUAS)
summary: The MQ-25 Stingray CBUAS program, after technical delays and fiscal reprogramming in FY23-FY24, is composed of the MQ-25A Stingray air vehicle and the Unmanned Carrier Aviation Mission Control System (UMCS) MD-5 Ground Control Station (GCS). Notably, the MD-5 GCS incorporates Lockheed Martin's Skunk Works® Multi Domain Combat System (MDCX™) for its operating consoles and computing systems, underscoring Lockheed Martin's involvement in the control infrastructure.

title: U.S. Navy MQ-25 Stingray Drone is Iran's Worst Nightmare
summary: The MQ-25 Stingray drone's recent low-speed taxi test on January 29, 2026, at Boeing's facility, marks a pivotal step towards its early flight this year. This unmanned refueling drone is portrayed as a significant advancement for naval aviation, capable of enabling stealthy refueling for fighters in contested airspace.

title: MQ-25 will fly in 2025, fly off carriers in 2026, says Navy's air boss
summary: Vice Adm. Daniel Cheever, commander of Naval Air Forces, expressed strong confidence that the US Navy's MQ-25 unmanned aerial tanker would achieve flight in 2025 and begin operating from aircraft carriers in 2026. He highlighted this as a critical step towards future manned-unmanned teaming capabilities and the integration of next-generation aircraft.

title: More RQ-21A Blackjack and ScanEagle drones to be purchased by U.S. Navy, international customers
summary: Insitu Inc. secured a $102.3 million contract modification to supply additional RQ-21A Blackjack and ScanEagle uncrewed aircraft systems (UAS) to the U.S. Navy and international partners. This modification increases the contract ceiling to acquire 21 RQ-21A Blackjack and 47 ScanEagle air vehicles, along with associated support equipment and training. The project is expected to be completed by June 2026.

title: Bangladesh Navy Inducts RQ-21A Blackjack UAVs
summary: The Bangladesh Navy has officially received a consignment of RQ-21A Blackjack small tactical unmanned aircraft systems (STUAS), making them the second operator of the Boeing-Insitu-made platform in Bangladesh. This acquisition is part of a broader US Indo-Pacific Strategy, marking a new phase in Dhaka's defense modernization and strengthening defense cooperation between Bangladesh and the United States. The RQ-21A is designed for runway-independent tactical intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) operations across both land and maritime domains.

title: U.S. Navy Orders RQ-21A Blackjack, ScanEagle UAVs for $102M
summary: The U.S. Navy awarded Insitu Inc., a Boeing subsidiary, a $102 million contract modification to acquire RQ-21A Blackjack and ScanEagle unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The contract includes the delivery of 21 RQ-21A Blackjack and 47 ScanEagle air vehicles, along with payloads, support equipment, spares, tools, and training. These systems are intended to support intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) missions for the Navy, Foreign Military Sales customers, and other international defense partnerships, with work anticipated to conclude by June 2026.

title: Insitu Secures $102M Navy Contract Modification for Drone Procurement
summary: Boeing's subsidiary Insitu has been awarded a $102.3 million contract modification from the U.S. Navy for the procurement of 21 RQ-21A Blackjack and 47 ScanEagle unmanned aircraft systems. The RQ-21A Blackjack is a small tactical UAS developed for land and sea operations, supporting communications relay, electronic warfare, and intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance missions. Its open payload architecture allows for customization with various communication systems, imagers, and signals intelligence capabilities.

title: RQ-21 Blackjack: The Tactical Drone That Changed the Way U.S. Marines Scout the Enemy
summary: The RQ-21A Blackjack, formerly known as the Integrator, is a small tactical unmanned aircraft system designed by Insitu, a Boeing company, for the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. This multi-intelligence aircraft system is deployed for persistent maritime and land-based tactical intelligence, surveillance, reconnaissance data collection, target acquisition, and dissemination missions. It is runway-independent, featuring an open architecture for customizable payloads including electro-optic imagers, infrared imagers, and laser rangefinders.

title: LM Skunk Works Showcases AI System That Can Reroute Drone Missions in Real Time
summary: Lockheed Martin's Skunk Works division demonstrated an AI system capable of autonomously managing mission disruptions across multiple unmanned platforms. During a test, the AI detected simulated fuel contingencies, generated new operational plans within seconds, and reassigned a Stalker's mission to an Alta X drone. This system aims to reduce operator workload and enhance resilient, distributed autonomous operations.

title: Lockheed Martin's Skunk Works unveils stealth combat drone
summary: Lockheed Martin's Skunk Works division unveiled plans for 'Vectis,' a stealthy combat drone designed to operate independently or alongside crewed aircraft like the F-35. The drone is capable of precision strikes, ISR targeting, electronic warfare, and offensive and defensive counter-air missions. This development highlights Lockheed Martin's focus on rapidly creating advanced, seamlessly integrated, and affordable autonomous technologies.

title: Lockheed Martin introduces STAR.OS to improve integration of AI systems for defence applications
summary: Lockheed Martin launched STAR.OS, a new AI integration framework designed to unify multiple artificial intelligence systems for national security operations. This technology allows different AI services to work together in real-time, addressing a long-standing challenge in the AI field. STAR.OS features a development toolkit, an interoperability layer, and an operator interface, and is already supporting maritime threat detection and missile warning systems.

title: Lockheed Martin unveils the Lamprey, a “revolutionary” new undersea drone concept
summary: Lockheed Martin announced the Lamprey Multi-Mission Autonomous Undersea Vehicle (MMAUV), a stealthy, multi-role undersea drone capable of attaching to other vessels to recharge and return to contested waters. Designed for covert reconnaissance, surveillance, mine countermeasures, and potential sabotage, the Lamprey aims to provide extended endurance and operational flexibility. This concept emphasizes stealth, versatility, and persistent undersea capabilities.

title: Lockheed Martin and MANTECH Partner to Advance AI Based Sustainment for U.S. Combat Aircraft Fleet
summary: Lockheed Martin and MANTECH announced a strategic teaming agreement to integrate advanced AI-driven sustainment solutions into the U.S. combat aircraft fleet. This collaboration aims to transform the defense supply chain through secure, scalable artificial intelligence. The partnership establishes a blueprint for strengthening America's defense industrial base.

title: Skunk Works® and XTEND Expand Joint All Domain Command and Control for Advanced Mission Execution
summary: Lockheed Martin Skunk Works® and XTEND collaborated to integrate the XTEND Operating System (XOS) into Skunk Works' MDCX™ autonomy platform. This partnership aims to expand Joint All Domain Command and Control (JADC2) capabilities for advanced mission execution. The collaboration focuses on enhancing human-machine teaming and accelerating autonomy.

title: Lockheed Martin Uses 5th Gen Fighter to Command Drone in Flight
summary: Lockheed Martin Skunk Works, with industry partners and the U.S. Air Force, successfully demonstrated controlling an uncrewed aerial system (UAS) from the cockpit of a 5th Generation fighter jet in flight. An F-22 Raptor pilot used a flexible pilot vehicle interface to command the drone, showcasing advanced human-machine teaming capabilities and the future of air combat. This effort is crucial for realizing the Air Force's vision of a family of systems.

title: Lockheed Martin Unveils Scalable Counter-Unmanned Aerial System Solution
summary: Lockheed Martin demonstrated a new scalable, layered defense system designed to detect, track, identify, and defeat small Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) and drone swarms. This modular, open-architecture solution combines combat-proven command and control with AI-enabled detection and track software, low-cost sensors, and various effectors. The system is designed for rapid deployment and seamless integration, enhancing operator efficiency against dynamic threats.

title: Lockheed Martin and BAE Systems Team Up for New Adaptable Multi-Effect Unmanned System
summary: Lockheed Martin and BAE Systems announced a partnership to develop a new range of uncrewed autonomous air systems. This collaboration leverages their expertise in rapid prototyping and advanced development to deliver game-changing capabilities for military customers. The initiative addresses the growing need for a mix of crewed and uncrewed assets and the rapid fielding of affordable 'combat mass'.

title: How Lockheed Martin is Using AI to Evolve PAC-3 Capability
summary: Lockheed Martin is investing in artificial intelligence and machine learning tools to enhance the capabilities of its PAC-3 MSE missile defense system. By integrating AI/ML techniques across the kill chain, the system aims to improve its ability to detect, track, and engage targets with increased precision and speed. This ongoing evolution allows PAC-3 MSE to adapt to new threat behaviors in real-time, providing a strategic advantage in missile defense.
